docs.lead_paragraph: BESET by rising costs and shrinking congregations, traditional Protestant churches that were once community mainstays in dozens of Long Island towns and villages are struggling to stay afloat. Although some of the Island's nearly 800 Protestant congregations are expanding or holding their own, many are selling property or renting church buildings to other congregations and private groups to make ends meet.

headline.main: In Church, Changing of the Guard

docs.abstract: Article on changes in traditional Protestant churches once mainstays of faith and culture on Long Island, NY; congregations are dwindling, resulting in financial problems particularly at small churches; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Carol Hochberg, an investment banker who turned a diagnosis of breast cancer into a life of advocating for fellow sufferers, died of the disease on Wednesday at her home on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. She was 40. When Ms. Hochberg learned of the cancer, her first reaction was to fight, said her mother, Audrey G. Hochberg, a Democratic Assemblywoman from Scarsdale, N.Y.

headline.main: Carol Hochberg, 40, Advocate For Victims of Breast Cancer

docs.abstract: Carol Hochberg, investment banker who became intense advocate for other breast cancer patients, dies at age 40; photo (S)
docs.snippet: Carol Hochberg, an investment banker who turned a diagnosis of breast cancer into a life of advocating for fellow sufferers, died of the disease on Wednesday at her home on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. She was 40.     When Ms. Hochberg learned...

docs.lead_paragraph: Lilia Cuji did not dare ask for welfare last summer when she ventured inside the Jamaica, Queens, outpost of the city's Human Resources Administration, a six-story brick building wedged between Caribbean delis and a topless bar called Dreams. Ms. Cuji, who immigrated from Ecuador six years ago, applied only for Medicaid health insurance benefits for her 2-year-old son, and she provided all the documents necessary to prove his eligibility. But in a little-noticed pilot project that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani plans to expand to the rest of the city next year, the Jamaica center required something more of anyone seeking Medicaid: a home investigation by the same city unit that screens welfare applicants for fraud.

headline.main: New Hurdle for Some Seeking Medicaid: Home Inspections

docs.abstract: New York City tightens Medicaid procedures instituting home investigations of applicants; Lilia Cuji, Ecuadoran who applied at Jamaica office for her son, says she was turned down after home investigator sharply questioned her lack of green card and spotted men's jeans in closet; official explains that further investigation may have found applicant misrepresented her situation and was living with spouse; welfare advocates admit procedures do permit city to uncover fraud; Cuji, whose husband also has no green card, later got Medicaid for child, and for herself because of pregnancy; some analysts say hard-line approach used to deter welfare fraud backfires on health care, because preventive treatment is cheaper than emergency-room care (M)
docs.snippet: Lilia Cuji did not dare ask for welfare last summer when she ventured inside the Jamaica, Queens, outpost of the city's Human Resources Administration, a six-story brick building wedged between Caribbean delis and a topless bar called Dreams. Ms....

docs.lead_paragraph: Denny Sansom of Mobil Oil has the ocean behind him, seven million restive Nigerians of the Niger River Delta in front of him, huge reserves of oil beneath him and hundreds of thousands of angry complaints against his corporation threatening to sink him. The trouble began on Jan. 12, he recalled. Mr. Sansom, a Texan who is Mobil's operations manager, walked into his 6:45 A.M. staff meeting and was told that despite full production at Mobil's 57 offshore wells, oil was not reaching shore. ''Shut it down!'' he hollered. ''Shut everything!''

headline.main: OIL RICH, OIL POOR: A special report.; High Claims in Spill Betray Depth of Nigerian Poverty

docs.abstract: Special report on Mobil oil spill off Nigerian coast in January, which has become subject of vehement dispute and catalyst for pent-up claims fed by poverty and state neglect; as Nigeria approaches delicate transition from military rule to democracy, delta region's long-festering problems pose threat of widespread violence; sabotage against pipelines is becoming routine, and poverty-stricken villagers are making huge financial demands on Mobil; since oil was discovered in delta region 42 years ago, enormous wealth has been taken by Western companies and by country's military rulers; now Mobil is facing billions of dollars in claims from population that feels it has been long ignored and Government of Gen Abdulsalam Abubakar is making conciliatory gestures but initiating little real reform; maps; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Denny Sansom of Mobil Oil has the ocean behind him, seven million restive Nigerians of the Niger River Delta in front of him, huge reserves of oil beneath him and hundreds of thousands of angry complaints against his corporation threatening to sink...

docs.lead_paragraph: Frances Randall Hunt, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Pratt Hunt of Washington, was married yesterday to Fletcher Maddox Jewett, a son of Dr. Leslie S. Jewett of Washington and Eugene A. Jewett of Alexandria, Va. The Rev. James L. Ulrich performed the Episcopal ceremony at Little Moose Lodge on Little Moose Lake in Old Forge, N.Y. Mrs. Jewett, 31, is known as Francesca. She is a merchandise assistant at Trout Unlimited, a conservation group in Arlington, Va. She graduated from the Cordon Bleu school in Paris. Her father is a retired senior official at the Central Intelligence Agency. Her mother, Randall Hunt, is an independent fine-arts appraiser. Mr. Jewett, 33, is an accountant in Washington. He graduated from the University of Maryland. His mother, who retired as the director of the Medlantic Institute, the physician education unit of Medlantic Health Care, a hospital company in Washington, is a jewelry designer and distributor in Washington. His father is a vice president for investments in the Washington office of Advest, a securities and insurance brokerage company.
docs.snippet: Frances Randall Hunt, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Pratt Hunt of Washington, was married yesterday to Fletcher Maddox Jewett, a son of Dr. Leslie S. Jewett of Washington and Eugene A. Jewett of Alexandria, Va. The Rev. James L. Ulrich performed...

docs.lead_paragraph: Tracy Susan Morelli, a daughter of Marianne and Robert A. Morelli of Old Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Dr. John Matthew Pramenko, a son of Karen and George R. Pramenko of Arvada, Colo. The Rev. Dr. Walter J. Smith performed the ceremony at St. Mary Roman Catholic Church in Greenwich. Mrs. Pramenko, 25, is a teachers' aide in second grade at Brown School in Schenectady, N.Y. She graduated from the University of Rhode Island and is a candidate for a master's degree in reading and special education at Russell Sage College. Her father is an insurance agent in Stamford, Conn. Her mother is the coordinator of the employee assistance program at UST Inc., the tobacco company, in Greenwich. Dr. Pramenko, 32, is a family physician at Schenectady Family Health Services. He graduated from the University of Colorado and received his medical degree from the University of Connecticut. His father, who formerly taught English in the public schools in Denver and Jefferson County, Colo., does research in Arvada into the political activities of the fundamentalist Christian right in Colorado. The bridegroom's mother is a head nurse for the Jefferson County schools.

docs.lead_paragraph: When the weather turns disastrous, or a Presidential campaign goes on the road, television news programs deliver the now-familiar images of America's agricultural heartland: wheat fields, tractors and two-lane blacktop. This week, ''The Farmer's Wife,'' on the PBS series ''Frontline,'' goes beyond those comforting vistas and inside the lives of a young Nebraska farm couple who struggle to keep their finances in order as they fight to save their marriage. The six-hour documentary, which will be broadcast over three nights, is the work of David Sutherland. He spent three years, and some 200 hours of film, exploring the lives of Darrel and Juanita Buschkoetter, who run a 1,100-acre grain and cattle farm near Lawrence, Neb., population 250.

headline.main: Down on the Farm, Where Anxiety Grows

docs.abstract: Comment on six-part Frontline television documentary The Farmer's Wife, on PBS; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL 3-26 Oil Spill Off Nigeria Is Catalyst for Complaints A huge oil spill off Nigeria's southern delta has provided a catalyst for pent-up claims in a region suffering from poverty and state neglect. Unrest in the area now seems close to boiling over, with sabotage against pipelines becoming routine and intermittent acts of violence. 1 Brazil's Pre-Election Storm Two weeks before Brazilians vote in Presidential elections, the financial tornado that has devastated parts of Asia and Russia has begun buffeting their own country. But President Fernando Henrique Cardoso, viewed as the most responsible figure to face the looming crisis, remains far ahead in opinion polls. 3 Yeltsin Role Seems to Fade As Russia's new Prime Minister struggled to patch together a coalition Cabinet last week, Boris N. Yeltsin seemed to remain largely in the background, adding to the growing impression that the once-powerful President has been left with a largely ceremonial role. 26 Swedes Go to the Polls Swedes go to the polls today to choose the 349 members of their parliament, and a multitude of municipal officials. The results will determine whether Prime Minister Goran Persson will remain in office or if Carl Bildt returns to the post, which he held from 1991 to 1994. 13 104 Still Missing in Philippines One hundred four people remained missing and 23 were confirmed dead after the sinking of a ferry early yesterday in the mouth of Manila Bay, in the Philippines. The authorities said that despite fierce winds and waves, 303 people had been rescued. The search for survivors continued. 11 NATIONAL 31-42 President's Testimony Reveals Strong Emotions In more than four hours of testimony before the grand jury on Aug. 17, President Clinton painted himself as a concerned and even tender friend to Monica S. Lewinsky, lawyers familiar with the proceeding said. That image is starkly at odds with that of the callous manipulator conducting an illicit affair portrayed in the report by Kenneth W. Starr, the Whitewater independent counsel. 1 Years of personal animosity and corrosive bitterness between President Clinton and Kenneth W. Starr, the independent counsel, have repeatedly clouded their judgment and led to excesses on both sides that have permanently tarnished both reputations, say associates of the two men. 1 At the Christian Coalition convention in Washington, many delegates said they were despondent about opinion polls showing that most Americans do not share the conviction that President Clinton should resign or be impeached. 34 Election Focus on Schools Across the country, scores of candidates for Senate and House seats are focusing on schools, vowing that if sent to Washington, they will get the Federal Government involved in cutting the nation's class sizes, repairing school buildings and making them safer for learning. 1 Lasker Awards for Research Six scientists who made discoveries dating to 1960 that identified the genetic basis of cancer and improved the diagnosis and treatment of certain types of the disease will receive this year's Albert Lasker awards. The recipients' findings and subsequent research have established that alterations in genes are the initial step in producing human cancer. 40 NEW YORK/REGION 43-49 A Town's Casino Idea Finds Nothing but Trouble Three years ago, the Mayor and business leaders of Wildwood, N.J., a struggling beach resort, had an inspired plan to open a casino by giving a piece of land back to Oklahoma's Delaware Indians, whose ancestors were pushed out of New Jersey in the 1830's. But it has backfired and mired the town in lawsuits. 1 In Queens, All That Jazz Hardly anyone remembers, but not all that long ago, in this city of jazz, Queens was, quite literally, the home of jazz. The clubs were in Harlem and on Broadway, but in the late 1930's and 40's, Louis Armstrong, Count Basie and other musicians had made enough money to leave the cramped hotels and apartments of Manhattan. 43 Medicaid Home Visits Criticized Applicants for Medicaid health insurance in Jamaica, Queens, are investigated by the same city unit that screens welfare applicants for fraud. Critics say expanding the plan would raise a frightening and unnecessary barrier to health care for many low-income children and adults. 43 Arrests at Book Warehouse The publisher of the Zagat Survey stopped a plan to steal thousands of its 1998 restaurant guides from a warehouse. 43 OBITUARIES 51 Cong. Vote 49 Weather 49

docs.lead_paragraph: A provision in a new Texas law allowing patients to sue health maintenance organizations and other insurers for malpractice was upheld today by a Federal judge. But a second provision, allowing patients to appeal to an independent panel when their employee health plan decides treatment is unnecessary, was struck down.

headline.main: A Mixed Verdict on Texas H.M.O. Law

docs.abstract: Federal Judge Vanessa D Gilmore upholds provision of new Texas law that lets patients sue health maintenance organizations and other insurers for malpractice; strikes down provision to let patients appeal to independent panel when their employee health plan decides treatment is unnecessary; rules in suit by Aetna Life Insurance Co and its Texas unit (M)

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: HEALTH MAINTENANCE ORGANIZATIONS AND MANAGED CARE

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: I do not believe that the health maintenance organization ''experiment'' has failed (letter, Sept. 15). The issue is not ''managed care'' per se. Managing care is an appropriate concept that addressed the problems of a fragmented and disease-oriented fee-for-service system with disincentives for cost constraint. In reaction to those problems, however, we got a profit-making system in which nurses and doctors lost control over care decisions to managers who understood little about patient care.
docs.abstract: Claire M Fagin reply to Sept 15 letter calls for revising, not discarding managed health care system (S)
